source.author: Mitsuo Sakamoto,1 Akiko Takagaki,2 Kohei Matsumoto,3 Yuko Kato,3 Keiichi Goto3 and Yoshimi Benno1
source.title: Butyricimonas synergistica gen. nov., sp. nov. and Butyricimonas virosa sp. nov., butyric acid-producing bacteria in the family ‘Porphyromonadaceae’ isolated from rat faeces

meta.other_info_on_meta: full citation: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology (2009), 59, 1748–1753

treatment.description: Urease and catalase are not produced. Gelatin is digested. Acid is produced from glucose and d-mannose, but not from l-arabinose, cellobiose, glycerol, lactose, maltose, d-mannitol, melezitose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, salicin, d-sorbitol, sucrose, trehalose or d-xylose. Positive reactions are obtained using Rapid ID 32A for α-galactosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, glutamic acid decarboxylase, α-fucosidase, indole, alkaline phosphatase and leucyl glycine, pyroglutamic acid, alanine and glutamyl glutamic acid arylamidases. Mannose is fermented. All other tests in Rapid ID 32A are negative. The major end product of the type strain is butyric acid; smaller amounts of acetic, propionic, succinic and isobutyric acids are produced. The major cellular fatty acid of the type strain is iso-C15 : 0 (66 %). The predominant respiratory quinone of the type strain is MK-10 (42 %); minor amounts of MK-8 (22 %), MK-9 (9 %) and MK-11 (27 %) are present. The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 46.4 mol%.
